conclusion: Analyze forces on each segment of the triangular conductor frame due to the magnetic field.
The frame is an equilateral triangle with uniform resistance wires, and the magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane.
Points A and B are connected to a power supply, creating a current through the triangle.
Current splits equally at each junction due to uniform resistance.
At point A, current splits into two equal parts, \( \frac{I}{2} \), flowing through AC and AB.
At point C, current from AC and BC combines to flow through CB.
Force on a conductor in a magnetic field is given by \( F = I \cdot L \cdot B \cdot \sin(\theta) \).
Since the magnetic field is perpendicular, \( \sin(\theta) = 1 \) for all segments.
The force on AB is \( F_{AB} = \frac{I}{2} \cdot L \cdot B \).
The current through AC and BC is \( \frac{I}{2} \) each.
The force on AC is \( F_{AC} = \frac{I}{2} \cdot L \cdot B \).
The force on BC is \( F_{BC} = \frac{I}{2} \cdot L \cdot B \).
Forces on AC and BC are equal in magnitude but opposite in direction, resulting in no net force along the horizontal axis.
The only net force is the force on AB, which is \( F \).
The magnitude of the resultant Ampere force on the three resistance wires is equal to the force on AB, which is \( F \).
